title.narrative: Building with Nature Indonesia: Securing eroding delta coastlines

description.narrative: Large-scale implementation of a Building with Nature pilot provides coastal security and supports revitalization of at least 6,000 ha of aquaculture ponds along a 20 km shoreline in Demak district (Central Java), thus enhancing the resilience of 70,000 vulnerable people. Further, the Building with Nature approach is mainstreamed in policies, plans and budget allocations for lowland development, disaster risk reduction, climate change adaptation and water safety in Indonesia. Northern Javas deltaic shorelines suffer from severe erosion and related flooding hazards, caused by mangrove conversion for aquaculture, groundwater extraction and infrastructure development. Over 30 million people in Java are at risk. The agri and aquaculture sectors, two engines to economic growth, have suffered multi-billion losses. Conventional hard-infrastructure solutions have been found to be ineffective, expensive and unable to adapt to climate change. Furthermore, they fail to bring back the economic, environmental and social benefits that healthy mangrove coastlines offer. The project introduces Building with Nature to accomplish resilience along eroding delta coastlines. This innovative approach combines civil engineering with mangrove rehabilitation to build safe and adaptive coastlines, while simultaneously introducing sustainable land use. First, through a large scale Building with Nature project in Demak district, we provide coastal security and support sustainable revitalization of 6,000 ha of aquaculture ponds along a 20 km shoreline. This enhances safety, inclusive economic growth and self-reliance of 70,000 vulnerable people. Technical measure to protect the coastline in Demak include restoration of the sediment balance using permeable dams and mud nourishments, alongside mangrove rehabilitation.

This project aims to enhance the resilience of 70,000 vulnerable people by implementing a building with nature pilot project, which provides coastal security and supports revitalization of at least 6,000 ha of aquaculture ponds along a 20 km shoreline.

participating-org.narrative: Directorate of Marine and Coast, DG-MSI of Marine Affairs

title.narrative: Water

description.narrative: Improved river basin management and safe deltas

title.narrative: Number of hectares of land under improved management

comment.narrative:
Safety depends on establishment of a coastal mangrove greenbelt along the entire coastline in the project area of Demak. To restore mangroves we are 1) restoring the sediment balance by placing permeable dams (target 90 ha of mangroves); 2) converting ponds back to mangroves (target 50 ha of mangroves) and 3) inspire others to follow suit. Re 1) Sedimentation rates behind the permeable structures are good and mangroves begin to recover. However, subsidence is counteracting progress and we now notice that it is much more severe than anticipated. Impact is being studied. Re 2) Communities have agreed to give up 50 ha of ponds, which is a great success. Restoration starts this year. Re 3) KKP and PUSAIR are also placing permeable structures in Demak in eroded areas. We are stepping up our communications in Demak. Success with 1 and 2 will help others to follow our example. This takes time.
424 hectare of ponds as supported by the biorights incentive mechanism
6000 ha safe: We may have reached a threshold where coastal restoration and aquaculture revitalisation in Demak may no longer be feasible at the landscape scale due to the severity of subsidence. Our assumption was that we could reduce coastal erosion and flooding by restoring mangroves to attenuate waves and currents, ultimately reducing flood extent once a wider greenbelt would have been established at the land-scape scale. However, strong subsidence in the Demak project area, especially in the Western part towards Semarang, is progressively rendering large swaths of land and villages below sea level. Although permeable structures and/or mangroves may still buffer against waves and may reduce erosion locally, they will not block water from flowing into the ever lower lying hinterland with high tides.

title.narrative: Number of people trained or skills developed - Total

comment.narrative:
Governments: Cumulatively training around 70 people rather than the targeted 100 (of which 15 trainers), which is related to an ideal group size of 25. We changed the target value accordingly.
Business (SMEs;): Construction training cumulatively 50 people
Coastal Field Schools: Community training 250 people (community leaders and others)
